CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: From the onset oxidation potentials ( E onset ox ) and the onset reduction potentials ( E onset red ) of the polymers , the HOMO and LUMO energy levels as well as the energy gap of the polymers were calculated using a ferrocene / ferrocenium ( Fc / Fc + ) redox couple ( 4.80 eV below the vacuum level ) as an external standard. 38-40 The HOMO energy levels of P1-P7 were determined to be -5. and LUMO energy levels , all polymers have enough driving force for efficient exciton dissociation with fullerene derivatives and they are all stable in air. 38 In Table 2 , E g CV was slightly larger than E g OPT in all polymers due to the exciton binding energy of the organic conjugated materials. 41,42 Photovoltaic Properties and Theoretical Calculations. The PSCs were fabricated with a structure of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / active layer / LiF / Al , where the polymers ( P1- P7 ) were used as electron donors and PC71BM ( or PC61BM ) was used as an electron acceptor. To optimize the morphology and ordering structure , different volume percentages of 1,8diiodooctane were added. 43 Figure 4 shows the current density versus voltage ( J-V ) curves for the devices under AM 1.5 illumination at 100 mW / cm^2. The V OC , J SC , FF , and PCE values of the PSC devices are summarized in Table 3. From P1 to P4 , PC71BM was used as an electron acceptor , but for P5 , P6 , and P7 , PC61BM was used as the electron acceptor. P5 , P6 , and P7 blended with PC61BM showed higher PCE values than when they were blended with PC71BM in spite of the better light absorption of PC71BM , which is most likely due to the lower miscibility of those polymers with PC71BM. 44 The V OC of these random terpolymers increased in the order P2 ( 0.74 V ) ∼ P3 ( 0.74 V ) < P4 ( 0.76 V ) < P5 ( 0.79 V ) < P6 ( 0.82 V ). The trend in the V OC of the PSCs can be explained by the HOMO energy level of the polymers because the V OC is typically linearly proportional to the difference in energy between the HOMO of the polymer and the LUMO of the acceptor. 45 However , the PCE of the random terpolymers showed a the nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% in the order P3 ( 5.61% ) > P4 ( 5.26% ) > P2 ( 4.91% ) > P5 ( 3.02% ) > P6 ( 2.09% ) ; this was consistent with the observed trend of the J SC . P3 exhibited the highest PCE value of 5.61% among all polymers , including P1 and P7 , which was attributed to the broad absorption and increased V OC due to the deeper HOMO energy level.

Let's think step by step.

Sure! Let's identify the "Material Name" entities in the given paragraph:

1. Polymers: The paragraph mentions the calculation of oxidation potentials (E onset ox) and reduction potentials (E onset red) of various polymers, including P1, P2, P3, P4, P5, P6, and P7.
2. Ferrocene/ferrocenium (Fc/Fc+): The paragraph mentions using a ferrocene/ferrocenium redox couple (4.80 eV below the vacuum level) as an external standard for calculating the HOMO and LUMO energy levels of the polymers.
3. Fullerene derivatives: The paragraph mentions that the polymers have enough driving force for efficient exciton dissociation with fullerene derivatives.
4. ITO/PEDOT:PSS/active layer/LiF/Al: The paragraph mentions the structure of the photovoltaic devices, which consists of an ITO (indium tin oxide) layer, a PEDOT (poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene)) layer, a PSS (polystyrene sulfonate) layer, an active layer, LiF (lithium fluoride), and an Al (aluminum) layer.
5. PC71BM/PC61BM: The paragraph mentions that PC71BM (or PC61BM) was used as an electron acceptor in the photovoltaic devices.

So, the "Material Name" entities in the paragraph are:

1. Polymers (P1, P2, P3, P4, P5, P6, and P7)
2. Ferrocene/ferrocenium (Fc/Fc+)
3. Fullerene derivatives
4. ITO/PEDOT:PSS/active layer/LiF/Al
5. PC71BM/PC61BM
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Of course! Here are the entities that refer to "Material Name" in the paragraph:

1. Polymers (P1, P2, P3, P4, P5, P6, and P7)

These are the entities that clearly refer to "Material Name" in the paragraph. I apologize for any confusion earlier.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Certainly! Here are the valid entities that refer to "Material Name" in the paragraph, presented in a Markdown table with one column "Material Name":

| Material Name |
| --- |
| Polymers (P1, P2, P3, P4, P5, P6, and P7) |

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.

To optimize the morphology and ordering structure , different volume percentages of 1,8diiodooctane were added. 43 Figure 4 shows the current density versus voltage ( J-V ) curves for the devices under AM 1.5 illumination at 100 mW / cm^2. The trend in the V OC of the PSCs can be explained by the HOMO energy level of the polymers because the V OC is typically linearly proportional to the difference in energy between the HOMO of the polymer and the LUMO of the acceptor. 45 However , the PCE of the random terpolymers showed a the nonlinear compositional dependence from 2 to 6% in the order P3 ( 5.61% ) > P4 ( 5.26% ) > P2 ( 4.91% ) > P5 ( 3.02% ) > P6 ( 2.09% ) ; this was consistent with the observed trend of the J SC . P3 exhibited the highest PCE value of 5.61% among all polymers , including P1 and P7 , which was attributed to the broad absorption and increased V OC due to the deeper HOMO energy level.

Sure! Let's identify the property names of materials mentioned in the paragraph:

1. Oxidation potentials (E onset ox)
2. Onset reduction potentials (E onset red)
3. HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) energy levels
4. LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) energy levels
5. Energy gap (Eg)
6. Polymers (P1-P7)

9. PEDOT (Poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene))
10. PSS (Poly(styrene-co-vinyl sulfonate))

14. PC71BM (7,7,8,8-tetracyano-9,9-diphenyl-5,6-benzothieno[3,2-b]thiophene)
15. PC61BM (6,6-diphenyl-5,6-benzothieno[3,2-b]thiophene)
16. V OC (Open Circuit Voltage)
17. J SC (Short Circuit Current)
18. FF (Fill Factor)
19. PCE (Power Conversion Efficiency)
